content.description:
Of all the fallen slabs, one still stands more or less straight and towers above the others.  Climb the steep side of it, start sitting on a detached block with your hands on the large ledge in the face.  Throw up to the edge and follow the arete to the point.  Bonus points if you fully top out and stand on the point of the boulder.



Roughly in the centre of the boulder jumble, very distinct.

Reasonably clean fall

Climb the next crack system to the right of Fern Gully After Dark.  It also doesn't top out owing to all the soil/vegetation.



The next crack system to the right of Fern Gully After Dark.

Clean fall

Climb the funky chimney/layback flake/offwidth leg jamming crack feature toward the climber's right end of the back wall.  There's not topout - you'd have to dig it out of too much dirt and vegetation, so content yourself with slapping the moss and downclimbing.



Behind all of the dominoes is the current face of the granite knoll they all peeled off of.  This is near the very end on the right side.

Awkward fall - there's a slab a short distance behind the climb and right in the fall zone.

Climb the corner crack system at the junction between the middle and right sections of the back wall.  It requires you to pull onto and through a big, detached deathblock wedged into the central corner crack.  It doesn't wiggle right now, but it's clearly just wedged in and has a horizontal split through the middle.  It won't last forever, and the house will win against some climber eventually.  Ready to roll the dice?



At the junction between the middle and right sections of the back wall.`

Decent soft fall, but a spotter will help you not topple backwards into the talus beneath Triple Cracks.

Climb the right arete on the first "domino" that fell off of the back wall.  Start sitting under the boulder on the slab behind it and stay under the boulder the whole way, reaching around the edge and heel hooking your way up.  Reach the thin top of the boulder and match to finish - there's nowhere to top out to.



The far right side of the first "domino" that fell off of the back wall - the back of the route directly faces the back wall.

A slab follows up behind you most of the way, so you can step back when you fall.

Climb the big, slabby splitter crack up the back of the first "domino" in front of the back wall.  Easy, fun, excellent.



On the back side of the first "domino" in front of the back wall (in front of the right side of it).

Soft fall, but be careful not to spill back in to the back wall.

The middle section of the has three obvious splitter cracks right next to each other.  Use whatever combination of the cracks and face crimps suits you to get to the top.  After a large flake ripped off the right side, the downward-flaring offwidth has actually become the easiest way to the top.  For full value, stay to the left-centre.



Toward the forward/left side of the middle section of the back wall.

Awkward talus fall - bring an extra pad to plug the gaps and cover the ankle-breakers.

Climb the large, overhanging crack splitting the boulder immediately to climber's right of the Monolith.  Start sitting on a large talus piece with your hands on a little ledge just under the crack and good feet down in the hole.  You get one easy move before you pull into a sustained, techy sequence to pull over the bulge and follow the crack to the top.  Good footwork is essential.  If you get it wrong, you'll not just fail but you'll fall into the crack to the left of the route and down into a horrible mosquito bog.  If you find your right hand flailing around without a good hold, you're not following the Way of the Fist.



Very clear left-leaning splitter crack on the boulder immediately right of the Monolith.

Fall is short but spicy.  A deep crack on one side, talus on the other.

The "first" bouldering area on the Hidden Valley approach. This will be the first exposed rock you see as you're crossing the muskeg. The area consists of row after row of thin, fallen blocks all radiating out from the same centre point. Many have fallen so that they can't be climbed, but those that haven't provide difficult and interesting bouldering. It's one of the more unique areas I've seen.

The area has several boulders and walls with established routes.  At the back of the area is a tall, vertical wall.  It's the current face of the granite knob all of the "dominoes" have fallen off of.  It has three sections.  On the left is a 20' section that is the further "forward" (toward the bog).  It ends in a blunt prow.  Another 20' section goes straight back from the prow and ends in a cracked corner.  A final 30' section goes straight to the right from this and has a few featured cracks and faces.  It ends in a boulder jumble.

In front of this is a thin boulder leaning away from it at a 35-degree angle.  There are slab climbs on the back and thin, overhung routes on the front.  A large crack splits all the way through it and can be climbed on either side.

The next row of boulders out from this is much thicker.  On climber's left are a few tall, slabby boulders with terrible falls.  On the right side of this row before the boulders become too short to climb is the large boulder split by the Way of the Fist crack.  In front of this row is the standalone Monolith.
